slides.title: Policy-level billing versus account-level billing
slides.originalNotes:
Policy-level billing versus account- level billing
With account-level billing, more than one policy can be invoiced using the same invoice stream. This means that an invoice can include invoice items from multiple policies.

For example, if the account has two policies that are invoiced monthly, both policies will be billed on the same invoices in the same invoice stream. In the diagram, both Policy X and Policy Y have the same payment interval, which is monthly- The periodicity of the invoice stream is also monthly- Thus, the policies share the same invoice stream.

Note: Account-level charges such as certain fees are always invoiced using an invoice stream with a Monthly periodicity, regardless of the paymentinterval of the policy.

slides.title: Periodicity and anchor dates for an invoice stream [5
slides.originalNotes:
Periodicity and anchor dates for an invoice stream
The Payment Interval field on the payment plan specifies how often billing can occur (that is, the invoicing frequency). The Periodicity field on an invoice stream specifies the frequency of the set of potential invoices contained in an invoice stream. BillingCenter uses the payment interval to select an invoice stream with a compatible periodicity.

Notice the Monthly periodicity supports several payment plan intervals. For example, a policy period with a Quarterly payment interval will use every third invoice in a set of potential monthly invoices.

An account has several Invoicing Dates fields. These settings on the account provide default anchor dates for invoice streams that belong to the account. For example, the value for Monthly Policies: Day of Month sets the anchor date for a monthly stream. Notice a payment interval of Twice Per Month requires two anchor dates.

slides.title: Assigning placement dates in account-level billing [5
slides.originalNotes:
Assigning placement dates in account-level billing
For both account-level and policy-level billing, invoice item placement dates for down payments and one-time charges (not shown in the slide) are assigned according to payment plan settings.

For account-level billing only, BillingCenter uses Invoicing Dates settings on the account for assigning the following:

Placement dates for installment invoice items (but not down payment and one- time charge items)
Anchor date or dates for the invoice stream, which determine the bill dates for invoices contained in the stream

In contrast to account-level billing, for policy-level billing, BillingCenter uses the payment plan settings for assigning all placement dates and invoice dates.

By handling placement dates and invoice dates differently for the two billing methods, BillingCenter solves the issue of invoice alignment in previous versions of BillingCenter. Refer to the BillingCenter Application Guide for details.

slides.title: Cutoff dates for placing items on invoices
slides.originalNotes:
Cutoff dates for placing items on invoices
Every invoice has a cutoff date. Invoice items are placed on the first chronological invoice whose cutoff date is on or after the invoice item's placement date.
The slide shows an example of how the cutoff date influences invoice item placement for account-level billing. The invoice item’s placement date is June 15th. The available invoices have bill dates on the 10th and due dates on the 21st.
If the payment plan's Item Placement Cutoff Date is set to Bill Date, the invoice item is placed on the July invoice- This is the first invoice whose cutoff date (the June 10th bill date) comes on or after the invoice item’s placement date (June 15th).

If the payment plan's Item Placement Cutoff Date is set to Due Date, the invoice item is placed on the June invoice- This is the first invoice whose cutoff date (the June 21st due date) comes on or after the invoice item’s placement date (June 15th).

Guidewire recommends that insurers using due date billing should use due date as the item placement cutoff and those using bill date billing should use bill date as the item placement cutoff. In the case of policy-level billing, the Fix Due Date/Bill Date & Item Placement Cutoff Date setting on the payment plan controls both the method for scheduling invoice dates and the invoice item cutoff date- This means for policy-level billing, the two values are always synchronized.

slides.title: Only 1 unapplied fund for account-level billing
slides.originalNotes:
Only 1 unapplied fund for account- level billing
All payments received by BillingCenter pass through an unapplied fund (T-account) before being allocated.

An account that uses account- level billing has only one unapplied fund: Default Unapplied. BillingCenter uses any positive balance in the unapplied fund to pay eligible invoice items belonging to any policy for which the account is the payer. This includes policies owned and paid by this account, account-level charges, and invoice items owned by other accounts or producers if they are assigned to this account for payment.

An account that uses policy-level billing can have either a single Default Unapplied fund or a separate unapplied fund for each policy. This topic is covered in the BillingCenter Introduction— Kickstart course. You can also refer to the BillingCenter Application Guide for details.
